Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships and Nanofabrication Experience: Successful Transitions from Community College to Graduate School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Binghamton University, State University of New York, is increasing the number of diverse, economically disadvantaged students pursuing careers in science and engineering disciplines. This program recruits economically disadvantaged students graduating from community colleges and prepares them for STEM careers with activities focused on nanofabrication technology. The goal is to increase the number of students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields. Recruiting activities include partnerships with regional community college and high school counselors and recruiting visits to community colleges and high schools. Scholarships are provided for 32 transfer students in their junior or senior years at Binghamton University. The program provides support for students through activities focused on skill development in the Binghamton University nanofabrication facility, the development of peer support networks, and mentoring. The program includes opportunities for 'learning by teaching' and 'learning by research' and investigates a new approach to improve student performance and interest. The program is testing a model for encouraging community college students to pursue advanced degrees in science and engineering disciplines. In addition, through outreach efforts and campus summer camps, this program engages younger students and high-school students in the exciting field of nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes Report: SSTEM Grant 1259968:  Scholarships and Nanofabrication Experience: Successful Transitions from Community College to Graduate School  

               Our NanoSTEM Grant 1259968 was focused on easing the transition of science and engineering-focused students from community colleges into our more rigorous university environment.  This cohort is at particular risk;  students were often the first in their family to go to college and did not have the same support structure or mindset as students who went directly to a four-year college. We gave special consideration to women and other underrepresented groups in selecting for this program. Our goals were to increase retention and facilitate success by providing financial and academic support and guidance.

               Admission to the NanoSTEM program also required the students to be active in research and community service or some sort of volunteer activity.  These requirements help the students get and stay involved in the University and give back to the community

               Recruitment involved visiting local and remote community colleges and communicating information about our program. Some recruiting was done by asking the Admissions Office to identify eligible students, who were then invited to apply.

Running the program was centered around a weekly seminar course, in which invited speakers would talk about subjects like time management and resumes. Students would also present once a year on their own individual research, which kept them accountable to the grant requirements. 

A central volunteer activity was a STEM (Science Technology Engineering and Math) day run by the students which featured a visit by one of the local school districts to Binghamton University.  The students would design interactive activities for middle students, who spend the morning at Binghamton, be exposed to the university and the science, and hopefully leave with more of an interest in STEM.  Meanwhile, the students in the program would get experience in presenting and teaching.

Most students did very well, and many thrived in the program.  One has been admitted into graduate school, and another is currently making a career as a STEM educator at Kopernick Observatory.  The vast majority of the rest have gone on to make successful starts as in their chosen careers in biotechnology, engineering, computer science, or other fields.

               Throughout the grant, we gave financial support to 37 different individuals. Recipients included 20 women, 6 people identified as Asian, 3 African-American, and two identified as native American.   Of that number, at least 31 have graduated as of this report, with median GPAs of 3.4. 

Overall, we are very satisfied with the outcomes of the program.  Details have been disseminated in the Frontiers of Education conference to encourage others to consider similar methods.
